title: 105_s2285
content:
The "Women's Progress Commemoration Act" declares the establishment of a Federal Commission to preserve historic sites related to the women's movement, starting from the Seneca Falls Convention in 1848. The "Women's Progress Commemoration Commission" is established with 15 members appointed by various leaders, who must have knowledge or expertise in relevant matters. The "Women's Progress Commemoration Commission" is established with 15 members appointed by various leaders, representing diverse economic, professional, and cultural backgrounds. The members may come from the public or private sector, academia, nonprofit organizations, or industry. The appointment process involves consultation among key leaders to ensure fair and equitable representation. The Women's Progress Commemoration Commission is established with 15 members appointed by various leaders to ensure fair representation of diverse backgrounds. Appointments must be completed within 60 days of the Act's enactment, with vacancies filled within 30 days. Meetings must be held within 30 days of the appointment process. The Women's Progress Commemoration Commission, consisting of 15 members appointed by various leaders, must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Subsequent meetings will be called by the Chairperson, with a majority of members forming a quorum for business transactions and hearings. The Commission will select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its members. The Women's Progress Commemoration Commission, with 15 appointed members, must identify historical sites significant to the women's movement and recommend actions for preservation and public education within a year of its initial meeting. The Commission also has powers under the National Historic Preservation Act. The Commission, with 15 members, can hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and appoint personnel to carry out its duties under the Act. The Commission members are compensated based on the Executive Schedule level IV rate for each day of duty. Travel expenses are also provided at authorized rates. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation should not exceed the rate for a level V position on the Executive Schedule. Other staff compensation can be determined by the Chairperson without following chapter 51 provisions. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint personnel without following civil service laws, with pay not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson can also procure temporary services at specified rates. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint personnel with pay not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 7. FUNDING: Appropriations authorized for Commission operations. Donations from non-Federal sources accepted.

SEC. 8. TERMINATION: Commission ends 30 days after report submission to Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 9. REPORTS TO CONGRESS: Secretary of the Interior to report to Congress on actions taken to preserve historical sites identified by the Commission. The curr_chunk can be summarized as: 

"Speaker of the House of Representatives and Vice President of the United States."
